lines.text: Enter the Constable of France, the LORD RAMBURES, ORLEANS, DAUPHIN, with others

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Tut! I have the best armour of the world. Would it were day!

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: You have an excellent armour; but let my horse have his due.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: It is the best horse of Europe.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: Will it never be morning?

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: My lord of Orleans, and my lord high constable, you talk of horse and armour?

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: What a long night is this! I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns. Ca, ha! he bounds from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs; le cheval volant, the Pegasus, chez les narines de feu! When I bestride him, I soar, I am a hawk: he trots the air; the earth sings when he touches it; the basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: He's of the colour of the nutmeg.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for Perseus: he is pure air and fire; and the dull elements of earth and water never appear in him, but only in Patient stillness while his rider mounts him: he is indeed a horse; and all other jades you may call beasts.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: No more, cousin.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my palfrey: it is a theme as fluent as the sea: turn the sands into eloquent tongues, and my horse is argument for them all: 'tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a sovereign's sovereign to ride on; and for the world, familiar to us and unknown to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at him. I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: 'Wonder of nature,'--

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my courser, for my horse is my mistress.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: Your mistress bears well.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Me well; which is the prescript praise and perfection of a good and particular mistress.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly shook your back.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: So perhaps did yours.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Mine was not bridled.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: O then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off, and in your straight strossers.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have my horse to my mistress.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his own hair.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I could make as true a boast as that, if I had a sow to my mistress.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement, et la truie lavee au bourbier;' thou makest use of any thing.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

lines.speaker: rambures
lines.text: My lord constable, the armour that I saw in your tent to-night, are those stars or suns upon it?

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Stars, my lord.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Some of them will fall to-morrow, I hope.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: And yet my sky shall not want.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and 'twere more honour some were away.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Even as your horse bears your praises; who would trot as well, were some of your brags dismounted.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will it never be day? I will trot to-morrow a mile, and my way shall be paved with English faces.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of my way: but I would it were morning; for I would fain be about the ears of the English.

lines.speaker: rambures
lines.text: Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: You must first go yourself to hazard, ere you have them.

lines.speaker: dauphin
lines.text: 'Tis midnight; I'll go arm myself.
Exit

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: The Dauphin longs for morning.

lines.speaker: rambures
lines.text: He longs to eat the English.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I think he will eat all he kills.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: By the white hand of my lady, he's a gallant prince.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: He is simply the most active gentleman of France.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: He never did harm, that I heard of.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Nor will do none to-morrow: he will keep that good name still.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: I know him to be valiant.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I was told that  by one that knows him better than you.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: What's he?

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: He needs not; it is no hidden virtue in him.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: By my faith, sir, but it is; never any body saw it but his lackey: 'tis a hooded valour; and when it appears, it will bate.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: Ill will never said well.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: I will cap that proverb with 'There is flattery in friendship.'

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: And I will take up that with 'Give the devil his due.'

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Well placed: there stands your friend for the devil: have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A pox of the devil.'

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: You are the better at proverbs, by how much 'A fool's bolt is soon shot.'

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: You have shot over.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: 'Tis not the first time you were overshot.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: My lord high constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Who hath measured the ground?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The Lord Grandpre.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were day! Alas, poor Harry of England! he longs not for the dawning as we do.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of England, to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge!

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: That they lack; for if their heads had any intellectual armour, they could never wear such heavy head-pieces.

lines.speaker: rambures
lines.text: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures; their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads crushed like rotten apples! You may as well say, that's a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their wives: and then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.

lines.speaker: constable
lines.text: Then shall we find to-morrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm: come, shall we about it?

lines.speaker: orleans
lines.text: It is now two o'clock: but, let me see, by ten We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.
Exeunt
PROLOGUE
Enter Chorus

lines.speaker: chorus
lines.text: Now entertain conjecture of a time When creeping murmur and the poring dark Fills the wide vessel of the universe. From camp to camp through the foul womb of night The hum of either army stilly sounds, That the fixed sentinels almost receive The secret whispers of each other's watch: Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames Each battle sees the other's umber'd face; Steed threatens steed, in high and boastful neighs Piercing the night's dull ear, and from the tents The armourers, accomplishing the knights, With busy hammers closing rivets up, Give dreadful note of preparation: The country cocks do crow, the clocks do toll, And the third hour of drowsy morning name. Proud of their numbers and secure in soul, The confident and over-lusty French Do the low-rated English play at dice; And chide the cripple tardy-gaited night Who, like a foul and ugly witch, doth limp So tediously away. The poor condemned English, Like sacrifices, by their watchful fires Sit patiently and inly ruminate The morning's danger, and their gesture sad Investing lank-lean; cheeks and war-worn coats Presenteth them unto the gazing moon So many horrid ghosts. O now, who will behold The royal captain of this ruin'd band Walking from watch to watch, from tent to tent, Let him cry 'Praise and glory on his head!' For forth he goes and visits all his host. Bids them good morrow with a modest smile And calls them brothers, friends and countrymen. Upon his royal face there is no note How dread an army hath enrounded him; Nor doth he dedicate one jot of colour Unto the weary and all-watched night, But freshly looks and over-bears attaint With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty; That every wretch, pining and pale before, Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks: A largess universal like the sun His liberal eye doth give to every one, Thawing cold fear, that mean and gentle all, Behold, as may unworthiness define, A little touch of Harry in the night. And so our scene must to the battle fly; Where--O for pity!--we shall much disgrace With four or five most vile and ragged foils, Right ill-disposed in brawl ridiculous, The name of Agincourt. Yet sit and see, Minding true things by what their mockeries be.
Exit
